Question 2

# Filter flights by month = 1 (January)
 flights_jan <- flights |> 
   filter(month == 1) |> 
   select(carrier,distance)
flights_jan
# A tibble: 27,004 × 2
   carrier distance
   <chr>      <dbl>
 1 UA          1400
 2 UA          1416
 3 AA          1089
 4 B6          1576
 5 DL           762
 6 UA           719
 7 B6          1065
 8 EV           229
 9 B6           944
10 AA           733
# ℹ 26,994 more rows
# Group the January flights by carrier
flights_jan_by_carrier <- flights_jan |> 
  group_by(carrier) |> 
  summarise(Mean = mean(distance), SD = sd(distance))
flights_jan_by_carrier
# A tibble: 16 × 3
   carrier  Mean    SD

Question 3

# Filtering the January Flights to see all flights from the two carriers of interest
flights_jan |> 
  filter(carrier == "OO")
# A tibble: 1 × 2
  carrier distance
  <chr>      <dbl>
1 OO           733
flights_jan |> 
  filter(carrier == "F9")
# A tibble: 59 × 2
   carrier distance
   <chr>      <dbl>
 1 F9          1620
 2 F9          1620
 3 F9          1620
 4 F9          1620
 5 F9          1620
 6 F9          1620
 7 F9          1620
 8 F9          1620
 9 F9          1620
10 F9          1620
# ℹ 49 more rows

We can see that the carrier 00 has only one distance recorded in January, and that F9 has many, but all of them are equal to 1620.

# Make objects containing all the rows of flight distances from each carrier
distance.00 <- flights_jan |> 
  filter(carrier == "OO") |> 
    select(distance)
distance.F9 <- flights_jan |> 
  filter(carrier == "F9") |> 
    select(distance)
distance.00
# A tibble: 1 × 1
  distance
     <dbl>
1      733
distance.F9
# A tibble: 59 × 1
   distance
      <dbl>
 1     1620
 2     1620
 3     1620
 4     1620
 5     1620
 6     1620
 7     1620
 8     1620
 9     1620
10     1620
# ℹ 49 more rows
# Find the standard deviation of each of the carriers January flights.
sd.00 <- distance.00 |> 
  summarise(SD = sd(distance))
sd.F9 <-  distance.F9 |> 
  summarise(SD = sd(distance))
sd.00
# A tibble: 1 × 1
     SD
  <dbl>
1    NA
sd.F9
# A tibble: 1 × 1
     SD
  <dbl>
1     0

Carrier “00” only has one distance (or row), and so cannot have a standard deviation, hence the standard deviation is “na”.

Carrier “F9” has many distances but they are all equal, hence standard deviation is equal to 0.

Question 4

# Flitering Flights for relevant columns
flights_dep_delay <- flights |> 
  select(month,dep_delay,carrier)

# A tibble: 336,776 × 3

# Averages per carrier per month
flights_dep_delay_averages <- flights_dep_delay |> 
  group_by(month,carrier) |> 
  summarise(avg_dep_delay = mean(dep_delay,na.rm = TRUE))
`summarise()` has grouped output by 'month'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.

Question 5

# Identify proportion of flights leaving late but arriving on time or earlier
prop_late_but_on_time <- flights |>
  summarise(
    proportion = mean(dep_delay > 0 & arr_delay <= 0, na.rm = TRUE)
  )
prop_late_but_on_time
# A tibble: 1 × 1
  proportion
       <dbl>
1      0.108

The proportion of flights out of the total flights that were delayed but still arrived on time is 0.1081096 or approximately 11%.

Question 6

6.1

# Identify unique combinations or origin, dest, and carrier
flights_routes <- flights |> 
  select(origin,dest,carrier) |>
  distinct() |> 
  group_by(origin,dest)
flights_routes
# A tibble: 439 × 3
# Groups:   origin, dest [224]
   origin dest  carrier
   <chr>  <chr> <chr>  
 1 EWR    IAH   UA     
 2 LGA    IAH   UA     
 3 JFK    MIA   AA     
 4 JFK    BQN   B6     
 5 LGA    ATL   DL     
 6 EWR    ORD   UA     
 7 EWR    FLL   B6     
 8 LGA    IAD   EV     
 9 JFK    MCO   B6     
10 LGA    ORD   AA     
# ℹ 429 more rows
# Isolate routes that are shared by multiple airlines
flight_routes_multiple_airlines <- flights_routes |> 
  count(origin,dest,name = "number_of_airlines") |> 
  filter(number_of_airlines>1)
flight_routes_multiple_airlines
# A tibble: 128 × 3
# Groups:   origin, dest [128]
   origin dest  number_of_airlines
   <chr>  <chr>              <int>

 2 EWR    AUS                    2
 3 EWR    BDL                    2
 4 EWR    BNA                    2
 5 EWR    BOS                    3

 8 EWR    CLE                    2

10 EWR    CVG                    2
# ℹ 118 more rows

6.2

# Identfiy all flights along the shared routes from Question 6.1
flights_multiple_airlines <- flights |>
  select(origin,dest,carrier,arr_delay) |>
  group_by(origin,dest,carrier) |> 
  semi_join(flight_routes_multiple_airlines,join_by(origin == origin, dest == dest))
flights_multiple_airlines
# A tibble: 276,735 × 4
# Groups:   origin, dest, carrier [343]
   origin dest  carrier arr_delay
   <chr>  <chr> <chr>       <dbl>
 1 JFK    MIA   AA             33
 2 LGA    ATL   DL            -25
 3 EWR    ORD   UA             12
 4 EWR    FLL   B6             19
 5 LGA    IAD   EV            -14
 6 JFK    MCO   B6             -8
 7 LGA    ORD   AA              8
 8 JFK    TPA   B6             -3
 9 JFK    LAX   UA              7
10 EWR    SFO   UA            -14
# ℹ 276,725 more rows
# Average flight delay for each airline along the shared routes
average_delay <- flights_multiple_airlines |> 
  summarise(mean_delay = mean(arr_delay,na.rm=TRUE))
`summarise()` has grouped output by 'origin', 'dest'. You can override using
the `.groups` argument.

# Added the names of each airline based on the "carrier" value from "airlines" data
average_delay_with_airline_name <- average_delay |> 
  left_join(airlines, by = join_by(carrier))

6.3

# The airline's with the worst average delay for each route
max_delay <- average_delay_with_airline_name |> 
  group_by(origin,dest) |> 
  slice_max(mean_delay)
max_delay
# A tibble: 128 × 5
# Groups:   origin, dest [128]
   origin dest  carrier mean_delay name                    
   <chr>  <chr> <chr>        <dbl> <chr>

# The airline's with the best average delay for each route

  group_by(origin,dest) |> 
  slice_min(mean_delay)

10 EWR    CVG   9E           1.40  Endeavor Air Inc.       
# ℹ 118 more rows
# Combining the two tables of the best and worst airlines for each route
max_and_min_delays <- max_delay |> 
  left_join(min_delay,by = join_by(origin, dest)) |> 
  rename(max_carrier = carrier.x,
         max_mean_delay = mean_delay.x,
         max_name=name.x,
         min_carrier = carrier.y,
         min_mean_delay = mean_delay.y,
         min_name = name.y)
max_and_min_delays
# A tibble: 128 × 8
# Groups:   origin, dest [128]

6.4

# Added "difference" column to measure difference between the best and worst airlines per route
differences <- max_and_min_delays |> 
  mutate(difference = max_mean_delay - min_mean_delay) |> 
  ungroup()
differences
# A tibble: 128 × 9
   origin dest  max_carrier max_mean_delay max_name   min_carrier min_mean_delay
   <chr>  <chr> <chr>                <dbl> <chr>      <chr>                <dbl>
 1 EWR    ATL   EV                   19.5  ExpressJe… 9E                  -6.25 
 2 EWR    AUS   UA                    4.28 United Ai… WN                 -11.2  
 3 EWR    BDL   UA                   22.6  United Ai… EV                   6.78 
 4 EWR    BNA   EV                   17.7  ExpressJe… WN                  -2.13 
 5 EWR    BOS   B6                    6.87 JetBlue A… EV                  -4.01

10 EWR    CVG   EV                   21.2  ExpressJe… 9E                   1.40 
# ℹ 118 more rows
# ℹ 2 more variables: min_name <chr>, difference <dbl>
# Identified route with biggest difference between best and worst airlines
greatest_diff <- differences |> 
  slice_max(difference)
greatest_diff
# A tibble: 1 × 9
  origin dest  max_carrier max_mean_delay max_name    min_carrier min_mean_delay
  <chr>  <chr> <chr>                <dbl> <chr>       <chr>                <dbl>
1 JFK    ATL   EV                     128 ExpressJet… 9E                    1.40
# ℹ 2 more variables: min_name <chr>, difference <dbl>

The route as per the above is JFK to ATL.

6.5

# Filtering for only the worst airline's flights along the route with the biggest difference
max_diff_flights <- flights |> 
  filter(origin == "JFK", dest == "ATL", carrier == "EV")
max_diff_flights
# A tibble: 1 × 19
   year month   day dep_time sched_dep_time dep_delay arr_time sched_arr_time
  <int> <int> <int>    <int>          <int>     <dbl>    <int>          <int>
1  2013    10     7      904            700       124     1133            925
# ℹ 11 more variables: arr_delay <dbl>, carrier <chr>, flight <int>,
#   tailnum <chr>, origin <chr>, dest <chr>, air_time <dbl>, distance <dbl>,
#   hour <dbl>, minute <dbl>, time_hour <dttm>
# Filtering for only the best airline's flights along the route with the biggest difference
min_diff_flights <- flights |> 
  filter(origin == "JFK", dest == "ATL", carrier == "9E")
min_diff_flights
# A tibble: 55 × 19
    year month   day dep_time sched_dep_time dep_delay arr_time sched_arr_time
   <int> <int> <int>    <int>          <int>     <dbl>    <int>          <int>
 1  2013     1     4      615            615         0      851            855
 2  2013     1     7      614            615        -1      812            855
 3  2013     1     8      612            615        -3      901            855
 4  2013     1     9      615            615         0       NA            855
 5  2013     1    10      613            615        -2      840            855
 6  2013     1    11      629            615        14      914            855
 7  2013     1    12      613            615        -2      839            855
 8  2013     1    13      612            615        -3      853            855
 9  2013     1    14      649            615        34      950            855
10  2013     1    15      612            615        -3      927            855
# ℹ 45 more rows
# ℹ 11 more variables: arr_delay <dbl>, carrier <chr>, flight <int>,
#   tailnum <chr>, origin <chr>, dest <chr>, air_time <dbl>, distance <dbl>,
#   hour <dbl>, minute <dbl>, time_hour <dttm>
# Histograms showing the disribution of all the flights along the route by the best and worst airlines
hist(max_diff_flights$arr_delay)
hist(min_diff_flights$arr_delay)

The difference arises due to the following. Firstly, on the JFK to ATL route, the airline 9E or Endeavor Air Inc, has many flights along this route with delays that appear to be normally distributed with a mean around 0, which can be seen in the “Histogram of min_diff _flights$arr_delay” plot above. On the other hand, the airline EV or ExpressJet Airlines only has one flight along the same route. In addition, that single ExpressJet Airlines flight had a very high arr_delay of 128, much higher than the maximum Endeavor Air delay of 55.

Having only a single flight results in a very high risk of an outlier skewing the results. In this case, 9E has a good average delay time, and due to EV’s one flight being so delayed, the difference between their averages is the biggest.

Question 7

# Importing Question 7 code into "data" object
data <- structure(list(id = c("id_1", "id_2", "id_3", "id_4", "id_5", 
"id_6", "id_7", "id_8", "id_9", "id_10", "id_11", "id_12", "id_13", 
"id_14", "id_15", "id_16", "id_17", "id_18", "id_19", "id_20",

Warning: Not all unique entries displayed for these non-numeric cols: id

From the above we can see that the columns that contain missing values include columns “height and”glucose”.

The column “gender” has one entry has a typo, as it says “femal” instead of “female”. Additionally, the “disease_status” column has one entry that has “Healthy” with a capital “H” whilst the other entries are “healthy” with a lowercase “h”.

Most columns that contain text are all lowercase, except for columns “region:” which all entries start with a capital letter, like “North” for example, and the “education” column, which has capitals in “PhD” entries.

The “id” column values all include the text “id_” which results in the column being formatted as “character” and not as “integer”. If you were to sort the data by the ID column the rows are not in the order you’d expect. As illustrated below, you can see the first row is “id_1” but then it jumps to “id_10” instead of “id_2”.

# Sorting data by the "id" column
class(data$id)
[1] "character"
data |> arrange(id)
